channel.title: Rianne van den Berg
channel.description: Recent content on Rianne van den Berg

item.description: About Me I am a postdoctoral researcher in machine learning at the University of Amsterdam under the supervision of Prof. Max Welling. My main research interest is deep generative modeling from a probabilistic point of view. In particular, I work on variational inference, normalizing flows and generative adversarial networks. More recently, I became interested in deep learning for dynamical systems described by differential equations. I am also interested in deep learning for graph-based data.

item.title: Teaching
item.description: I am an instructor and coordinator for the following course: Machine Learning 1, Master’s program in Artificial Intelligence at the University of Amsterdam. I was a teaching Assistent for the following courses: MBA Big Data & Business Analytics: Machine Learning, at the Amsterdam Business School. Electrodynamics, Quantum Mechanics, and Statistical Physics at the University of Amsterdam

item.title: Graph Convolutional Neural Networks for Recommender Systems
item.description: In this project the application of graph convolutional neural networks to recommender systems is discussed. T. Kipf and M. Welling introduced graph convolutional neural networks in [1] and [2] and applied this method to semi-supervised classification tasks and link prediction on general graphs. Here, we apply these methods to recommender systems, for which the interaction data can be represented by bipartite graphs.

item.title: Information retrieval for financial regulations
item.description: During the 5 week Science to Data Science workshop in London organized by Pivigo I worked as a Data science fellow in a team of 4 for the startup Waymarktech. Their core product revolves around automating the search for relevant financial regulations for their clients, and establishing the appropriate course of action that the client needs to follow to become compliant. We delivered a proof of principle of the ability to extract information from regulations using techniques from Natural Language Processing, such as tf-idf, PCA and word2vec.
